senses.sense_definition: Compassionate mercy or pity, often used in a religious, literary, or dramatic context to denote a plea for forgiveness or relief.

examples.text: The prisoner fell to his knees and cried out for <w>misericordia</w> from the conquering king.
Her eyes were filled with <w>misericordia</w> as she looked upon the suffering of the poor.

senses.sense_definition: A thin-bladed dagger used in the Middle Ages to deliver the death stroke to a wounded knight.

examples.text: The knight drew his <w>misericordia</w> to end the agony of his fallen opponent.
He carried a sharp <w>misericordia</w> at his belt for use in close combat.

senses.sense_definition: A charitable institution or hospital, historically managed by a religious order to provide care for the poor, sick, and orphans.

examples.text: The sick man was taken to the local <w>misericordia</w> to receive medical attention.
Donations were collected from the townspeople to support the work of the <w>misericordia</w>.

senses.sense_definition: An arbitrary fine or amercement imposed by a court, historically used in feudal law when a penalty was not fixed by statute.

examples.text: The defendant was placed in <w>misericordia</w> for failing to appear before the court.
The judge ordered a <w>misericordia</w> to be paid to the king for the offense.

senses.sense_definition: A religious song or chant sung as part of a service to ask for God's mercy.

examples.text: The choir began to sing a solemn <w>misericordia</w> as the procession moved into the church.
He heard the monks chanting a <w>misericordia</w> for the souls of the departed.

senses.sense_definition: A relaxation of monastic rules, specifically regarding fasting or diet, or the room where such meals were eaten.

examples.text: The monks gathered in the <w>misericordia</w> to eat meat during the festival days.
The abbot granted a <w>misericordia</w> to the elderly brothers, allowing them better food.
